fields.name: Victor Nițu
fields.bio:
Self-taught in the technology field, caught somewhere between hacking new bits of free software and UNIX systems administration and development.

Since the involvement with Fundația Ceata, been trying to fill the gaps between various professions, using software as a glue and The Sponge as a place to meet the necessities of others.

He and Ioana Cristea built the Open Media Challenge hackathon platform and the teams collaboration software.

He currently is the CTO of Ceata and a volunteer in various free software projects.

fields.name: Ștefan Cândea
fields.bio:
Stefan Candea is a freelance journalist and co-founder in 2001 of the Romanian Centre for Investigative Journalism (CRJI), an investigative non-profit registered in Bucharest, Romania.

He is the co-founder and coordinator of European Investigative Collaborations, a network started late 2015. Stefan is also working on his PhD research with the University of Westminster, as an EIJC fellow, analyzing the structures of cross-border investigative networks.   

Stefan started Sponge, an open and collaborative media innovation Lab for Eastern Europe. The Lab created this in-depth magazine, a lifeboat for journalism in the region.

He teaches investigative journalism at Bucharest University and was the 2011 Carroll Binder Nieman Fellow at Harvard University.

Between 2012 and mid 2013 Stefan coordinated, on behalf of CRJI, the ICIJ Eastern Europe research and reporting Hub for the Offshore Leaks Project. "Secrecy for Sale: Inside the Global Offshore Money Maze" was probably the largest cross-border investigative reporting collaboration in history and has been cited more than 25,000 times by other media organizations around the world.

Since March 2001, he has been a correspondent for Reporters sans Frontieres in Romania.

Candea is a member of International Consortium for Investigative Journalism and has won several awards including the IRE Tom Renner Award, the Overseas Press Club of America Award for online journalism.

He worked for Deutsche Welle, for print, radio, TV and online and he did freelance research and production work for several foreign media outlets, including the BBC, Channel 4, ITN, ZDF, and Canal Plus.

Other investigations by Candea have included the international arms trade, illegal international adoption, an investigation of the separatist region of Trans-Dniester and the diamond business in Romania.

He started as an investigative journalist for the Evenimentul Zilei newspaper in Bucharest, in 1999, where he covered the connections between international organized crime networks and high-ranking politicians and public servants. One article showed the links between La Cosa Nostra and associates of the Romanian president and the foreign secret service director.

fields.name: Petrut Calinescu
fields.bio: I was born in Constanta, at the Black Sea. Eversince I was a kid, lying on the beach, I was dying to find out what was happening on the other side of the sea. Years have passed, and in the meantime I have worked as a photographer for various Romanian newspapers and magazines. I am a freelancer since 5 years now, and it is not necessarily that I want this, but I work for the international mass-media more often than for the local media. A list of the recent publications can be seen right here. I am supported in finding clients for photos by the following agencies: Panos Pictures, Getty Images, Shoot the Earth. I have earned several photography awards, I’ve had numerous group exhibitions – in June 2010 I am exhibiting my photos in Germany, within the Lumix Festival for Young Photojournalism. Personal photographic projects in Kenya, India, Bolivia, Afghanistan, Egipt, Romania – they may be seen on my site, www-petrut-calinescu.com.

fields.name: Alex Ulmanu
fields.bio:
I strive to find new ways to tell stories. That's why, although I love writing, I've also embraced DSLR video, and I have been into podcasting, audio slideshows and various tools that help us reach audiences that are diverse and engaged.

Besides being a writer and multimedia journalist, I am also a trainer. For the Black Sea project, my focus is on the impact of religious differences on people's lives. My reporting has been supported in part through a generous grant from the International Reporting Project.

fields.name: Monica Ulmanu
fields.bio:
Monica Ulmanu is a freelance graphics journalist currently working from her home town, Bucharest. Before returning to Romania, she worked for The Boston Globe and The New York Times. Also studied hard as a Tar Heel and earned a master's degree in visual communication at the School of Journalism and Mass Communication, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

She worked on the design and usability of TheBlackSea.eu website, with the desire to create engaging opportunities for the team of journalists to display their multimedia work.

You can find her on Twitter as @monicaulmanu.

fields.name: Cristea Ioana
fields.bio:
Self-trained as web platforms coder, she co-founded a free software developing
company and got involved in various tech projects within The Sponge portfolio.


The most recent projects count The Black Sea publishing platform (still in
development) and a PHP framework (still in development / standardization /
documentation process).

fields.name: Michael Bird
fields.bio:
UK-born Michael Bird has been in love with eastern Europe ever since watching Elton John's video for 'Nikita' and falling for the border guard with 'eyes like ice on fire'.

After travelling extensively through the ex-Communist region during the 1990s in search of this woman - in vain - he settled in Bucharest, where he is now a journalist, writer and TV presenter who specialises in long-form features on major social, political and business issues in southeast Europe.

For The Black Sea he has travelled to Ukraine, Romania, Georgia and Moldova to investigate the impact of problem drug use on fragile economies, including recording the stories of addicts and survivors of substance abuse.

For his work for The Black Sea covering the HIV epidemic in eastern Europe, he is winner of the 2014 Award for Best Initiatives of European Online Investigative Journalism, Robert Schuman Centre for Advanced Studies (European University Institute, Florence, Italy).

Major projects he has worked on include Football Leaks in 2016/2017. This is a series of articles from the largest leak in sports history undertaken in a cross-border project with European Investigative Collaborations spanning 14 countries, leading national media outlets and over 60 journalists. In 2016, he has also worked on Eurocrimes, a data journalism project revealing the nationalities of criminals in 25 EU countries.

Previously his work has appeared in the Independent on Sunday, Politico, Tagesspiegel, Ukraine Today, Design Week, the New Statesman, EU Observer, Druglink magazine, Business Insider, The Diplomat - Bucharest and throughout the national press of Romania and the Republic of Moldova. He has reported for Deutsche Welle, and been interviewed on Romanian protests in 2017 for the BBC and Al Jazeera.

Twitter: @MichaelBirdUK

fields.name: Vlad Ursulean
fields.bio:
In high school in Romania, I started a magazine that ended up in a great scandal and almost got me expelled. This experience was so intriguing that I went on to study journalism and write for newspapers and magazines.
I am now a freelancer working on features and investigations about deep issues in Romania. I live in Casa Jurnalistului, an independent journalism collective space in Bucharest.

fields.name: Adrian Mogoș
fields.bio:
Journalist Adrian Mogos is currently the head of investigations at the Bucharest daily Jurnalul National.

Previously he was a writer for Romanian newspaper Evenimentul Zilei in Bucharest and a weekly magazine in Timisoara.

He is a member of the Romanian Center for Investigative Journalism and was a fellow at Balkan Fellowship for Journalistic Excellence.

His reporting on social issues, illegal deforestation, organized crime and corruption has been cited by judges of the Global Shining Light Award, Kurt Schork Award and CEI-SEEMO Award. One of the stories he supervised, on modern slavery, was included in the UNESCO Global Casebook for Investigative Journalism.

fields.name: Sorin Ozon
fields.bio:
Sorin Ozon is a freelance journalist and a co-founder of the Romanian Centre for Investigative Journalism (CRJI). He was director of the CRJI from 2001 until 2011.
As an investigative journalist he has written about connections between cross-border networks of organized crime and high level politicians and public functionaries. A series of articles he has written show links between Sicilian crime syndicate Cosa Nostra and associates of the former President of Romania and former director of the Romanian foreign secret service, the SIE.
He began working as a reporter in 1992 at daily newspaper Ora. He has been chief of the investigative department at Romanian dailies Jurnalul National and Evenimentul Zilei. At Jurnalul, he was also deputy editor. Sorin worked as a special reporter at satirical weekly Academia Catavencu and at Evenimentul Zilei.

fields.name: Vlad Odobescu
fields.bio:
I'm a freelance features writer, recently converted to investigative journalism. For five years, until mid-2011, I was special correspondent for bestselling Romanian newspaper Evenimentul zilei.

During my work as a correspondent there, I covered mainly social subjects usually labeled as marginal by mainstream media. For one of my stories, I was awarded the best feature writing in 2011 by the Romanian Press Club. In January 2012, I won the 'European Reporter 2011', competition organized by The Representation of the European Commission and the European Parliament Information Office in Romania.

In December 2011, I became a member of The Romanian Centre for Investigative Journalism. After a nine months experience as an editor for the Romanian portal of Yahoo! News Romania, I started a freelance career. My stories have been published by media outlets such as USA Today, Bloomberg BNA and Dilema Veche. Between January and March 2013, I worked as a reporter-in-residence with The New England Center for Investigative Reporting (NECIR) in Boston. For the last few months, The Balkan Fellowship for Journalistic Excellence, awarded by The Balkan Investigative Reporting Network (BIRN), was the perfect continuation of this learning experience.

fields.name: Dimiter Kenarov
fields.bio: Dimiter Kenarov is a freelance journalist, poet, literary critic, translator – a writer, really. He was born and raised in Sofia, Bulgaria, studied in the United States (Middlebury College; University of California – Berkeley), and now lives on the road, but mostly in Istanbul, Turkey, where he shuttles back and forth between two continents and drinks lots of tea. He is the author of two collections of Bulgarian poetry and a book of translations of the selected poems of Elizabeth Bishop. His English-language writing has appeared in Esquire, Outside, The Nation, Foreign Policy, Boston Review, The International Herald Tribune, The Virginia Quarterly Review, and The Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, among many others. His work has also been anthologized three times in The Best American Travel Writing (2009; 2012; 2013) and has been twice labeled “notable” in The Best American Non-Required Reading. He is a member of The Association of European Journalists – Bulgaria.

fields.name: Lina Vdovîi
fields.bio:
I am a Moldovan-born journalist with experience in investigative journalism, narrative journalism and new media. I started working as a reporter in 2008 for Opinia Studenteasca in Iasi, Romania. Before moving to Bucharest, where I work as online editor for Romanian Public Television, I participated in the project CNN iReport University and received one of the European scholarships for journalists, offered by Freedom House Romania. 

In December 2012, I joined Romanian Centre for Investigative Journalism. My articles were published in outlets such as Dilema Veche, Decat o Revista, The Industry, Courrier International and Euobserver.com.

fields.name: Kristine Aghalaryan
fields.bio:
Kristine Aghalaryan is a journalist working for the NGO the Investigative Journalists of Armenia, which publishes the online magazine Investigative www.hetq.am (hetq means footprint in Armenian).

She covers social, legal and mostly environmental issues. In 2012 she won a contest 'Sustainable Energy for All' organized by UNDP/GEF for an environmental investigative story on small hydro-electric plants and the owners of the plant.

fields.name: Grisha Balasanyan
fields.bio:
Grisha Balasanyan is a journalist working for the NGO the Investigative Journalists of Armenia and Hetq (ww.hetq.am). He covers social, political and legal issues. In 2013 he won the journalism prize on “Judicial Amendments” implemented in Armenia.

Grisha Balasanyan is a lawyer and a member of Chamber of Advocates of the Republic of Armenia.

fields.name: Crina Boros
fields.bio:
Romanian Crina Boros is an investigative journalist reporting on HSBC leaks, UK and offshore money-laundering, Afghan victims’ compensation, women’s rights, EU lobbying, workers’ abuse, conflict of interest and lobby.

She specializes in Freedom of Information and data-driven stories and has reported for Thomson Reuters Foundation, BBC, Exaro News, The Centre for Investigative Journalism and OffshoreAlert.

She also conducts training in computer-assisted reporting. Member of Investigative Reporters and Editors (IRE).

fields.name: Caelainn Barr
fields.bio: Caelainn Barr is an Irish journalist based in New York. She is currently a Stabile investigative fellow at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism and has worked at the Bureau of Investigative Journalism in London. Her work has been published in the Financial Times, the Guardian, The Independent and The Irish Times and broadcast on BBC Newsnight.

fields.name: Elena Lomoră
fields.bio:
Elena Lomora is a Master's Student in political science and Russian and East European Studies at the University of Helsinki. She is interested in the conditions of women in the former communist countries.

Elena is now writing her thesis about the representation of women in Romanian high school textbooks and writes for the Black Sea as part of an Erasmus work placement scholarship.

For this project, she has been working out of the cities of Cluj-Napoca and Bucharest, Romania.

fields.name: Annina Lehmann
fields.bio: Annina Lehmann currently lives and works in Tbilisi. After receiving a BA in Politics, Philosophy and Economics from the University of Oxford in 2011, she went on to complete an MA in Comparative Literature at Goldsmiths College, University of London. Since then she has spent time in Romania and the Caucasus, writing and researching stories relating to marginalised communities, drug policy as well as national and cultural identity. In addition to writing, she makes short films and installations.

fields.name: Tako Robakidze
fields.bio: Tako Robakidze was born in 1987 in Tbilisi. In 2008 she graduated from Tbilisi State University faculty of Law. She took a master's degree in journalism at Caucasus University School of Media. From 2004 to 2008 she studied at the documentary photography studio “Sepia”. Since June 2014 she is a co-founder and member of the Georgian photo agency ERROR IMAGES.

fields.name: Rina Soloveitchik
fields.bio: Rina Soloveitchik holds a BA in Politics, Philosophy and Economics from the University of Oxford and an MSc in Human Rights from the London School of Economics and Political Science. Currently she works for the Europe and Central Asia Program of a major international organization and as a freelance journalist. Her articles appeared in Moscow Times, Kyiv Post, Vice News and The International Security Observer. Based in London she frequently travels to Kyiv, Moscow and Tbilisi.

fields.name: Craig Shaw
fields.bio:
Craig Shaw is a British journalist and former Bertha Fellow at the Centre for Investigative Journalism in London. 

Specialising in corruption, human rights issues, his work has featured in leading media such as The Guardian, The Sunday Times, L’Espresso, Expresso, De Correspondent and others. He often works on cross-border investigations, including the European Investigative Collaborations' Football Leaks project -  for The Black Sea -, ICIJ's Offshore Leaks, and Mafia in Africa, and Mafia in Africa 2.

He also produces stories on Turkey for The Black Sea and other outlets.

Twitter: @cpshaw

fields.name: Roman Anin
fields.bio:
Roman Anin is an award-winning Russian investigative reporter at Moscow-based weekly newspaper Novaya Gazeta.

Specialising in government and military corruption, Anin has produced a series of reports into the assassination of business leaders by a criminal organisation, led by the son of General Vladimir Shamanov, head of Russia’s Airborne Forces.  He has also written about corruption among politicians and businessmen involved in construction contracts for the Sochi Olympic Games.

In 2013, Anin won the Knight International Journalism Award. The year before, he won the Artem Borovik award, the Youlian Semenov award and the Andrey Sakharov award. He is also a member of the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists.

fields.name: Nicoleta Banila
fields.bio:
Bucharest-based Nicoleta Banila has been writing for Romanian business newspaper Capital, English politics and economics magazine The Diplomat Bucharest and other media projects such as The Investigations Journal, Renne and Green Report.

She is now working as a freelance journalist and full time web designer.

fields.name: Claire Provost
fields.bio:
Claire Provost is an investigative journalist following the money in international aid and global development. She is currently a Bertha fellow at the Centre for Investigative Journalism in London, and was formerly four years at the Guardian.

Provost's has published in The Guardian, The Independent, and International Business Times, among other publications, reporting on human rights, development, and the impacts of multinational corporations from more than a dozen countries, from El Salvador to Ukraine.

Recent projects include investigations into the obscure international legal system that lets companies sue countries, and the growing role of multinational corporations in designing, delivering, and profiting from international aid efforts.

Provost holds degrees from Harvard and Columbia universities.

fields.name: Luke Dale-Harris
fields.bio: Luke Dale-Harris is an investigative reporter based in Romania and the UK. His work on land rights, corruption and environmental crime has been published widely in magazines and newspapers including Newsweek, The Guardian and Der Spiegel Online.

fields.name: Sorin Semeniuc
fields.bio: Sorin Semeniuc is an award winning journalist and member of the Romanian Centre for Investigative Journalism. He is the founder of the investigative news website www.ziardebuzunar.ro and holds a PhD for his thesis on the relationship between the language of journalism and that of politics.

fields.name: Diana Mesesan
fields.bio: Diana Mesesan is a Romanian freelance journalist and photographer, passionate about people and their stories. She has written for The Diplomat - Bucharest, Romania-Insider, Decat o Revista and Think Outside the Box. For Diana, the best part of her work is reporting. She has experience in narrative journalism and multimedia.

fields.name: Andrei Becheru
fields.bio:
Born in 1984, I studied industrial design at the National University of Arts Bucharest and graduated in 2007.

After college, I worked as a graphic designer. but gradually I started to learn photography.

In 2008, I began “The Fountain”, a long-term project about life in Dobrogea, published in “BURN Magazine”(2012) and in “Formaje: Romanian Art Files” (2013) Magazine.

Currently I am a freelance photographer and the images taken for documenting the project “Light for Romania” in 2014-2015 have appeared in publications including Reader’s Digest, Dilema Veche, Adevărul, Romanian National Television (TVR1), Internazionale (Italy), Arte.tv and Radio France Internationale.

fields.name: Sorina Vazelina
fields.bio: Sorina Vazelina is a sort of graphic designer, illustrator and cartoonist born and schooled in Romania. She has worked in two visual communication studios, so far: Synopsis Media, in Timișoara, and It's Everyday, in Bucharest. Her work has been published by Hardcomics, Kus Komics, Centrala UK and Novo Doba Belgrade. She used to be a regular contributing illustrator for Esquire, Playboy and Regard magazine. Some of the projects she's been involved in include: the visual identity for the White Night of Galleries in Bucharest, 100towatch.ro and The Book of George, a compendium of Romanian cartoonists. In 2015 she won the prize for best book in a limited edition, at the Most Beautiful Books in Romania competition (Cele Mai Frumoase Carti). To find out more deliriously puzzling information on her work, visit vazelina.ro.

fields.name: EIC 2016
fields.bio:
European Investigative Collaborations: partnering on in‐depth reporting at source   
 
We believe in building an investigative network. Due to their structure and methodology, collaborative networks are the only mechanism able to keep step with the globalized power structures (ie. governments,  corporations), and the single way forward for investigative journalism. Our primary purpose is joint reporting and publication of investigative journalism with a focus on European topics to understand how power structures impact European  communities.
 
EIC partners offer different and complementary mind-sets, organization types and skills. This ensures a flow of new challenges, ideas and approaches. Our aim is to build a  European network focusing on independent, high-quality cross-border and European investigative journalism projects.
 
Discussions on forming this network started in 2015 and involved Der Spiegel and the Romanian Centre for Investigative Journalism. Le Soir joined the plan as well as Politiken, Newsweek Serbia, Falter, El  Mundo, TheBlackSea, Mediapart and L'Espresso. These are all funding partners of EIC. During the coming months EIC will decide on future partnerships related to stories or tools development. This is a non-exclusive Network, meaning that members can be part of other Networks, but only one medium or media outlet from each European country can be an EIC member, ensuring national exclusivity. 
 
The basis for cooperation among EIC member organizations is the regular sharing of information and consultations on possible story ideas. We have regular meetings and work on several fronts: tackling European stories; finding, compiling, processing or analyzing big data-sets; developing under Free Software license our own Network collaborative tools, platforms and information design.

fields.name: Margherita Bettoni
fields.bio:
Margherita Bettoni is a freelance reporter based in Germany.

She mostly writes about organized crime and her works has been published in various media outlets.

fields.name: Feliciano Tisera
fields.bio: An Argentinian-born journalist based in Spain, Feliciano writes for www.bez.es

fields.name: Cecilia Ferrara
fields.bio:
Cecilia Ferrara is a freelance journalist, a member of IRPI (Investigative Reporting Project Italy) and contributor to Radio Bullets.

She graduated in European Contemporary History at the University of Florence. From 2000, she working as a journalist in the communitarian radio station Novaradio, in Florence. She gained interest in the Balkans and became an expert in Balkan politics, society and organised crime, living – between 2007 and 2010 – in Sarajevo and Belgrade. In that period she freelanced for several Italian and international media such as Il Venerdì (La Repubblica), Osservatorio Balcani and Caucaso, Left, Avvenimenti, Europa, Transition on line, Le Jeudì, Narcomafie, Avvenire, Carta, Peacereporter and Rinascita. 

In 2011 she co-authored the book Narconomics on the international traffic of cocaine and heroine. At the moment she works on transnational investigative journalism projects.

fields.name: Paulius Ramanauskas
fields.bio: Paulius Ramanauskas is a Lithuanian journalist.

fields.name: Sigute Limontaite
fields.bio: Sigute Limontaite is a Lithuanian journalist based in the UK.

fields.name: Zeynep Sentek
fields.bio:
Zeynep is a Turkish academic and journalist specialising in investigations, human rights, workers' rights, and military issues.   

Zeynep holds an MA in Conflict and Security from the University of Sussex in the UK, and is currently a doctoral researcher at Heidelberg University in Germany, studying Turkish civil-military relations.

Follow Zeynep on Twitter

fields.name: Costin Stucan
fields.bio: Costin Stucan is a Romanian investigative journalist specialised in sport, who is currently working at Gazeta Sporturilor in Bucharest.

fields.name: Elizabeth Short
fields.bio: Elizabeth Short is a journalist who has also written for The Calvert Journal.

fields.name: Alex Morega
fields.bio: Alex Morega has worked on Football Leaks.

fields.name: Blaz Zgaga
fields.bio: Blaz Zgaga is a Slovenian journalist.
